newsitem.title: USA: Ford U.S. sales fell in May, capping slow month.
newsitem.headline: Ford U.S. sales fell in May, capping slow month.

text.p: Domestic car and light truck sales fell 5.8 percent in May, marking the second consecutive month of softer demand, as Ford Motor Co. Wednesday reported a 3 percent sales decline for the month.

The Ford results -- comparatively better than those of Chrysler Corp. and General Motors Corp. -- mirrored the industry trend of relatively strong truck sales offset by chronic weakness in passenger car sales.
"May is a clear signal that we're reaching a saturation point in demand," said John Casesa, an auto analyst with Schroder Wertheim & Co. "Incentives continue to go up, and sales are not going up."

Overall, industry sales fell 5.8 percent to 1.4 million units in May, which was good enough for a seasonally adjusted annual sales rate of about 14.8 million units, significantly below the 15.4-million rate a year earlier and the robust first-quarter rate of 15.6 million vehicles.
Despite the booming economy, strong consumer confidence, and low unemployment and inflation, there are fewer and fewer consumers who have not already bought a new car or truck in recent years.

Lower used car prices -- a result of leases that have put more high-quality used cars and trucks on dealer lots -- have drawn buyers away from new cars. In addition, second-quarter sales are suffering somewhat because heavy promotions pulled some sales into the first quarter.
"I expect that June will see a snap-back in demand," said George Magliano of the WEFA Group in New York. "We'll be alright in the next quarter."
He estimated that sales for 1997 will be about 14.9 million cars and light trucks, down from 15.1 million in 1996.

Ford said its North American-built car sales fell 11.8 percent to 150,185 units while light-truck sales, fuelled by strong demand for sport utility vehicles, rose 5.2 percent to a company record of 206,087 units.
Ford's sales declines were below the 16.6 percent overall May sales drop reported by Chrysler and the 8.1 percent drop reported by GM this week.

Ford continued to be bullish about light truck demand, and confirmed plans to add 15,000 trucks, mainly Windstar minivans, to its second-quarter production schedule. As a result, Ford intends to build 772,000 trucks in the quarter, up 13 percent from a year earlier.
Ford also said it added 5,000 cars to its second-quarter schedules, which would put output at 466,000 cars, a 14 percent decline from a year ago.

GM's sales, hurt by two assembly plant strikes, included a 5.4 percent increase in truck sales -- also to a company record -- and a 16.7 percent drop in car sales. Chrysler's car sales fell 17.9 percent, while truck sales, hurt by an engine plant strike, fell 15.5 percent.

Ford's truck record was fuelled largely by a 47 percent increase in sales of sport utility vehicles to 58,879 units. Much of the credit was due to the full-size Expedition, which analysts estimate hauls in $10,000 in profits per unit.

Ford also plans July 1 to introduce the new, even more luxurious Lincoln Navigator luxury sport utility vehicle, which is based on the Expedition. The No. 2 U.S. automaker said it has dealer orders for about 11,000 Navigators.
